initial_story: the aim of this paper is to provide a classification of multilingual andplurilingual electronic lexicographic resources which would enable, one the onehand, the implementation of quantitative and qualitative criteria to produce atypological taxonomy of lexicographical tools, such as dictionaries, as opposedto platforms and websites and, on the other, the distinction of multilingualand plurilingual resources in terms of their larger or lesser prototypingdegree. in addition to offering a thorough description of the differentresources, this paper also puts forward some parameters and typologicalproposals to define and demarcate a number of electronic resources,particularly multilingual dictionaries and portals, while also outlining, andeven questioning, the object of study of multilingual and plurilinguallexicography.
stories: moreover, this paper will delve into the complexities of categorizing electronic lexicographic resources, examining the nuances of multilingual and plurilingual approaches, and exploring the implications of these distinctions on the development of lexicographical tools. a critical analysis of existing taxonomies and classification systems will be undertaken, with a view to identifying gaps and areas for improvement, and proposing a novel framework that can effectively capture the diversity and complexity of electronic lexicographic resources. by doing so, this research aims to contribute to the advancement of multilingual and plurilingual lexicography, and to provide a foundation for future studies on the design, development, and evaluation of electronic dictionaries, portals, and other lexicographic tools.

Furthermore, this study will investigate the role of user needs and expectations in shaping the development of electronic lexicographic resources, with a particular focus on the requirements of diverse user groups, including language learners, professionals, and scholars. A mixed-methods approach will be employed, combining both quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis methods, including surveys, interviews, and usability testing. The findings of this research will inform the design and development of a prototype electronic dictionary that incorporates the proposed novel framework, and its usability and effectiveness will be evaluated through a series of user studies. Ultimately, this research aims to bridge the gap between theoretical and practical approaches to lexicography, and to provide a comprehensive understanding of the complexities and challenges involved in creating electronic lexicographic resources that meet the needs of a diverse and multilingual user base.

The research will also explore the potential of incorporating emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence and natural language processing, into electronic lexicographic resources, and examine their impact on the user experience and the effectiveness of these resources. Additionally, the study will investigate the role of crowdsourcing and collaborative approaches in the development and maintenance of electronic dictionaries, and assess their potential for fostering community engagement and participation. The outcomes of this research will contribute to the development of innovative and user-centered electronic lexicographic resources that cater to the diverse needs of language learners, professionals, and scholars, and will inform the development of best practices and guidelines for the design and development of electronic dictionaries in the digital age.

Furthermore, the study will delve into the possibilities of integrating multimodal and multimedia features, such as images, videos, and audio recordings, into electronic dictionaries, and analyze their impact on the learning experience and retention of linguistic knowledge. The research will also explore the potential of using gamification and game-based learning principles to enhance user engagement and motivation in electronic lexicographic resources. Moreover, the study will investigate the role of electronic dictionaries in promoting linguistic diversity and preserving endangered languages, and examine the implications of digital lexicography for language policy and planning. By examining the intersection of technology, language, and culture, this research aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the evolving landscape of electronic lexicography and its applications in the digital age.

In addition, the study will investigate the opportunities and challenges of crowdsourcing and collaborative dictionary-making, as well as the potential of artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms to improve the accuracy and efficiency of electronic dictionaries. The research will also consider the ethical implications of digital lexicography, including issues of accessibility, equity, and cultural sensitivity, and explore the ways in which electronic dictionaries can be designed to promote social justice and linguistic equality. Through a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative and qualitative data, this study aims to provide a nuanced and multifaceted understanding of the complex relationships between language, technology, and culture, and to inform the development of innovative and effective electronic lexicographic resources that meet the needs of diverse language learners and users in the 21st century.

The study will also examine the role of electronic dictionaries in language preservation and documentation, particularly for endangered languages, and investigate the potential of digital lexicography to support language revitalization efforts. Furthermore, the research will explore the intersection of digital lexicography with other fields, such as natural language processing, human-computer interaction, and language teaching, and identify opportunities for interdisciplinary collaboration and knowledge sharing. By analyzing the impact of electronic dictionaries on language learning, language teaching, and language policy, this study will provide insights into the ways in which digital lexicography can contribute to the promotion of linguistic diversity and multilingualism in a rapidly changing world.

The study's findings will also inform the development of best practices for the creation and dissemination of electronic dictionaries, and provide recommendations for policymakers, educators, and language communities on how to harness the potential of digital lexicography to support language preservation, language education, and language rights. Additionally, the research will investigate the role of electronic dictionaries in promoting linguistic equality and social justice, particularly in contexts where languages are marginalized or stigmatized. By examining the intersection of digital lexicography with issues of power, identity, and social inequality, this study aims to contribute to a more nuanced understanding of the complex relationships between language, technology, and society.

Furthermore, the study's outcomes will have significant implications for the development of inclusive language policies and the promotion of linguistic diversity in the digital age. By exploring the ways in which electronic dictionaries can be designed and utilized to empower marginalized language communities, this research will provide valuable insights for policymakers, educators, and language activists seeking to promote linguistic justice and challenge dominant language hierarchies. Ultimately, this study aims to demonstrate the potential of digital lexicography to serve as a powerful tool for language revitalization, cultural preservation, and social change, and to inspire a new generation of language researchers, developers, and advocates to harness the power of technology to promote linguistic equality and human rights.

Through a critical examination of the role of electronic dictionaries in shaping language attitudes and policies, this study will contribute to a deeper understanding of the complex relationships between language, power, and identity, and will provide a framework for the development of inclusive and culturally sensitive language resources that reflect the diversity of human experience. By foregrounding the voices and perspectives of marginalized language communities, this research will challenge dominant narratives and power structures, and will promote a more nuanced and equitable understanding of the complex dynamics of language and culture in the digital age.

Furthermore, this study will also investigate the ways in which electronic dictionaries perpetuate or challenge linguistic hegemonies, and how they can be designed to promote linguistic diversity and multilingualism. Through a mixed-methods approach combining qualitative and quantitative data, this research will provide a comprehensive analysis of the impact of electronic dictionaries on language attitudes and policies, and will offer recommendations for the development of language resources that are responsive to the needs of diverse language communities. Ultimately, this study aims to contribute to a more inclusive and equitable language landscape, where the linguistic and cultural diversity of human experience is valued and celebrated.

By examining the role of electronic dictionaries in shaping language attitudes and policies, this research will shed light on the complex power dynamics at play in the language landscape, and will provide insights into the ways in which language resources can be designed to promote social justice and linguistic equality. Moreover, this study will explore the potential of electronic dictionaries to serve as tools for language revitalization and language preservation, particularly in the context of endangered languages and minority language communities. Through its focus on linguistic diversity and multilingualism, this research will also contribute to a broader understanding of the importance of language in shaping identity, culture, and community, and will highlight the need for language resources that are responsive to the diverse needs and experiences of language users around the world.

Furthermore, this study will investigate the ways in which electronic dictionaries can be used to challenge dominant language ideologies and promote linguistic diversity, particularly in contexts where language policies have historically favored a single, dominant language. By examining the role of electronic dictionaries in language education and language planning, this research will provide a nuanced understanding of the complex relationships between language, power, and identity, and will offer practical recommendations for the development of language resources that are inclusive, equitable, and socially just. Ultimately, this study aims to contribute to a more just and equitable language landscape, where linguistic diversity is valued and celebrated, and where language resources are designed to promote social cohesion, mutual understanding, and respect for linguistic and cultural diversity.

To achieve this goal, the study will employ a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative and quantitative data from a range of sources, including surveys, interviews, and content analysis of electronic dictionaries. The research will focus on three case studies, each representing a different language context: a multilingual African country, a bilingual European country, and a Indigenous language community in the Americas. By comparing and contrasting these case studies, the research will identify patterns and trends in the use of electronic dictionaries to promote linguistic diversity and challenge dominant language ideologies. Additionally, the study will engage with language educators, policymakers, and community members through participatory action research, ensuring that the research is grounded in the needs and perspectives of those most affected by language policies and practices.

The participatory action research component will involve a series of workshops and focus groups, where stakeholders will collaborate to develop and test innovative language education strategies that incorporate electronic dictionaries and other digital resources. This collaborative approach will not only ensure the relevance and applicability of the research findings but also empower language educators, policymakers, and community members to become agents of change in promoting linguistic diversity and social justice. Furthermore, the study will develop a set of guidelines and recommendations for the effective integration of electronic dictionaries into language education policies and practices, with the aim of creating more inclusive and equitable language learning environments.

These guidelines and recommendations will be disseminated through a variety of channels, including academic publications, conference presentations, and online resources, to reach a broad audience of language educators, policymakers, and community stakeholders. Additionally, the study will establish a network of language education professionals and community leaders who will continue to collaborate and share best practices in promoting linguistic diversity and social justice beyond the duration of the project. This network will provide a sustainable platform for ongoing dialogue, knowledge sharing, and innovation in language education, ultimately contributing to a more inclusive and equitable society where linguistic diversity is valued and celebrated.

The network will also facilitate the development of language education policies and practices that are responsive to the needs of diverse communities, and will provide a framework for evaluating the effectiveness of language education programs in promoting social justice and linguistic diversity. Furthermore, the study's findings and recommendations will be translated into multiple languages to ensure accessibility and reach a wider global audience, and will be disseminated through social media and other online platforms to engage with a broader public and spark meaningful conversations about the importance of linguistic diversity and social justice.

In addition, the network will establish partnerships with international organizations, government agencies, and community groups to promote the implementation of language education policies and practices that prioritize social justice and linguistic diversity. This will involve providing training and resources for educators, policymakers, and community leaders to develop their capacity to design and deliver language education programs that are responsive to the needs of diverse communities. The network will also establish a clearinghouse for language education resources, including curricula, teaching materials, and assessment tools, to support educators and policymakers in their efforts to promote linguistic diversity and social justice.

Furthermore, the network will facilitate research collaborations and knowledge sharing among its members to identify and address the linguistic and educational needs of under-resourced communities, and to develop innovative solutions that can be replicated and scaled up in different contexts. This will involve establishing a peer-reviewed journal and organizing regular conferences, seminars, and workshops to showcase best practices, share research findings, and provide a platform for stakeholders to engage in critical discussions and debates. Additionally, the network will develop a system of advocacy and policy influence to ensure that the voices and concerns of marginalized communities are heard and represented in language education policy-making at local, national, and international levels.

To achieve this, the network will establish partnerships with local community organizations, educational institutions, and government agencies to ensure that its research and advocacy efforts are informed by the needs and perspectives of under-resourced communities. It will also develop a range of resources, including language teaching materials, teacher training programs, and assessment tools, that are tailored to the specific needs of these communities. Moreover, the network will provide opportunities for capacity building and professional development for language educators, researchers, and policymakers, enabling them to develop the skills and knowledge needed to design and implement effective language education programs. By fostering a community of practice and promoting collaborative research and innovation, the network aims to drive systemic change and promote greater equity and social justice in language education.

Through its activities, the network will prioritize the empowerment of under-resourced communities, supporting their efforts to reclaim and revitalize their linguistic and cultural heritage. It will also facilitate the development of inclusive language policies and practices that recognize the diversity of languages and cultures, and promote the value of linguistic diversity as a key component of social cohesion and economic development. Furthermore, the network will engage in international dialogue and collaboration, sharing best practices and lessons learned with other organizations and networks working towards similar goals, to amplify its impact and contribute to a global movement for language education equity.

Additionally, the network will provide training and capacity-building opportunities for educators, community leaders, and policymakers, enabling them to develop the skills and knowledge necessary to create and implement effective language education programs that cater to the needs of diverse student populations.
